questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about posterior cruciate ligament (PCL)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Exp:

– PCL is the only primary restraint to posterior translation throughout the entire knee range of motion (ROM).

– PCL is an Extra Synovial Structure approximately twice as strong and twice as thick as the normal ACL (therefore less commonly injured)

•	Dimesions:

– Size: 13 mm, its length, 38 mm, (approximates that of ACL);

– Origin:

PCL originates from the antero-lateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch;

– Its origin is much more anterior than that of ACL

•	It is the largest subdivision of a lobe and is separated from adjacent segments by connective tissue.

It is surgically resectable

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as she can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. A residual volume of 1.0 liter is determined using the helium dilution technique. What is her FRC (in liters)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

3.0

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. It is composed of two sub-volumes:

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled from the end of a normal expiration.
Residual Volume (RV): The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal expiration.
The formula for FRC is: FRC = ERV + RV

From the provided spirogram:

The normal end-expiratory level (the baseline of the smaller undulations representing tidal breathing) is at 3.0 liters on the Y-axis (Volume).
The lowest point achieved after a maximal exhalation (the trough of the large downward curve) is at 1.0 liter on the Y-axis. This 1.0 liter represents the volume of air that cannot be exhaled, which is the Residual Volume (RV). This is consistent with the problem statement explicitly giving the residual volume as 1.0 liter.
Now, let's calculate ERV:

ERV = (Volume at end of normal expiration) - (Volume at end of maximal expiration)
ERV = 3.0 liters - 1.0 liter = 2.0 liters
Finally, calculate FRC:

FRC = ERV + RV
FRC = 2.0 liters + 1.0 liter = 3.0 liters
Incorrect Options:

Option (A. 2.0)
Explanation: This value represents the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) only, not the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC). FRC also includes the Residual Volume (RV).

Option (B. 2.5)
Explanation: This value does not correspond to any standard lung volume or capacity directly derivable from the given data. It might arise from misreading the graph or incorrect calculation.

Option (D. 3.5)
Explanation: This value appears to be the end-inspiratory level of a normal tidal breath (3.0 L + 0.5 L tidal volume), or the peak of the normal tidal breathing, not the FRC. FRC is the volume remaining after a normal expiration, which is 3.0 L in this case.

questions.text: Menke's disease a rare X-linked recessive progressive multisystemic disease  caused by mutation in the ATP7A gene results in which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Copper deficiency

ATP7A gene encodes ATP7A, which is an active copper (Cu) transporter. ATP7A is a transmembrane protein predominantly expressed in enterocytes, the placenta, and the central nervous system, where, at a steady state, it directs Cu to Cu-dependent enzymes. In low to normal copper states, the ATPase is localized in the trans-Golgi network (TGN), which is retained by Acetyl-CoA transporter 1. In the TGN, ATP7A transfers copper from the cytoplasm into the Golgi complex for the metalation of multiple cuproenzymes. If copper levels are high, it effluxes out of the cell by relocating to the plasma membrane.[9]

The clinical features of Menkes disease are either a direct consequence of enzyme dysfunction or secondary to an inability to load these enzymes with Cu.[10] The failure of ATP7A in the enterocytes leads to subsequent failure of the efflux pump and causes excessive Cu accumulation in the enterocytes with generalized Cu deficiency. The enzymes requiring copper for important biochemical functions include cytochrome C oxidase, dopamine beta-hydroxylase, lysyl oxidase, tyrosinase, superoxide dismutase, and peptidyl glycine alpha amid monooxygenase.[11][12] The cytochrome oxidase deficiency affects cellular respiration and causes CNS degeneration and ataxia. Autonomic symptoms, including hypotension and hypothermia, are due to abnormal catecholamine synthesis from deficient dopamine beta-hydroxylase. Menkes disease also exhibits marked connective tissue abnormalities, including skin, joints, and bone abnormalities, and impaired blood vessel integrity due to the absence of lysyl oxidase and defective cross-linking of collagen and elastin.[13] Skin hypopigmentation and hair abnormalities are due to abnormal tyrosinase and sulfhydryl oxidase, respectively.

Profound neurological features are due to low Cu in the brain. Likely explanations include:

•	Cu gets trapped in the blood-brain and blood-cerebrospinal fluid barriers, while glial cells and neurons are deprived of Cu.

•	Generally, Cu is the noncompetitive antagonist of NMDA receptors. Normally, ATP7A mediates the availability of NMDA receptors and a releasable pool of copper in hippocampal neurons. The absence of ATP7A markedly accentuates the NMDA receptor excitability in the neurons, causing seizures.[14]

•	The deficiency of cytochrome C-oxidase causes accumulations of superoxide radicals and neuronal damage.

•	Impaired blood vessel integrity with secondary ischemia leading to infarction due to deficiency of lysyl oxidase.

questions.text: Which of the following pathogens falls under Category A of bioterrorism agents?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Category A bioterrorism agents are those that are considered the highest priority agents for bioterrorism.

•	Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, falls under Category A because it can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, results in high mortality rates, has the potential for major public health impact. 

•	The other options listed (Salmonella, Escherichia coli, and Clostridium difficile) are important pathogens but are not categorized as Category A bioterrorism agents.

choices.text: Quality of labour room and maternity operation theatre services
Provision of postpartum family planning counselling

questions.text: Under the LaQshya initiative, what specific aspect of maternal and newborn healthcare facilities does the program aim to improve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	The LaQshya initiative, launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in India, specifically aims to improve the quality of labor room and maternity operation theatre services in healthcare facilities. 

•	This initiative focuses on ensuring that these facilities meet certain quality standards to enhance the safety and well-being of both mothers and newborns during childbirth. 

•	It includes improving infrastructure, availability of essential equipment and supplies, adherence to clinical protocols, infection control measures, and training of healthcare providers to provide quality care during labor and delivery.

questions.text: What is the recommended duration of multidrug therapy (MDT) for paucibacillary leprosy under the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: 

•	Under the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP), the recommended duration of multidrug therapy (MDT) for paucibacillary leprosy is indeed 6 months.

choices.text: Life expectancy, literacy rate, and infant mortality rate
Life expectancy, literacy rate, and income
Access to clean water, sanitation facilities, and healthcare services
GDP per capita, unemployment rate, and inflation rate

questions.text: The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) includes which of the following indicators?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to gauge the overall well-being and quality of life in a country or region. It includes indicators related to basic human needs and health outcomes. The correct option (a) includes indicators that are commonly used to calculate the PQLI:

1. Life expectancy at 1 year: 

2. Literacy rate: 

3. Infant mortality rate:

questions.text: Which level of disease prevention does self-breast examination primarily fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Self-breast examination primarily falls under the category of secondary prevention. 

•	Secondary prevention aims to detect and treat diseases in their early stages, before symptoms become apparent or complications develop. Self-breast examination is a method by which individuals examine their own breasts regularly to detect any changes, such as lumps or abnormalities, which could indicate the presence of breast cancer. Early detection through self-breast examination allows for timely medical intervention, potentially leading to better treatment outcomes and improved survival rates

questions.text: In a cohort study investigating the effect of dietary habits on the incidence of type 2 diabetes, 3000 participants without diabetes at baseline are followed for 5 years. Among those who consume a high-sugar diet ( > 50% of daily calorie intake from added sugars), 200 individuals develop type 2 diabetes. In contrast, among those who consume a low-sugar diet ( < 10% of daily calorie intake from added sugars), 50 individuals develop type 2 diabetes. What is the relative risk of developing type 2 diabetes associated with a high-sugar diet compared to a low-sugar diet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

RR= Incidence among exposed/ Incidence among Non exposed

Incidence among exposed = 200/3000

Incidence among non-exposed = 50/3000

RR= 4

questions.text: A clinical trial is conducted to assess the effectiveness of a new drug in lowering blood pressure. The study involves 100 participants, and their blood pressure measurements before and after treatment are recorded. Which statistical test should be used to determine if there is a significant difference in blood pressure before and after treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paired T-test

A Paired T-test (or dependent sample T-test) would be used because the same participants are measured before and after treatment. This test assesses whether the mean difference between paired observations is significantly different from zero.

questions.text: At what age is the Pentavalent vaccine typically administered to children under NIS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: 

Pentavalent vaccine typically administered to children under NIS at 6, 10, 14 weeks.

choices.text: Distributing physical vaccine doses to healthcare facilities.
Providing a platform for citizens to schedule vaccination appointments.
Conducting clinical trials for new vaccines.

questions.text: What is the role of the logo shown in the vaccination process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is logo of U-Win.

questions.text: Which component is commonly found in vaccines to enhance the body's immune response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	An adjuvant in vaccines serves to enhance the body's immune response to the antigen (the active ingredient that stimulates an immune response). 

•	Adjuvants can also help improve the effectiveness of vaccines in certain populations, such as the elderly or those with weakened immune systems.

•	One example of an adjuvant used in vaccines is aluminum salts (alum). 

•	Aluminum salts have been used as adjuvants in vaccines for decades. 

•	Aluminum salts are commonly used in vaccines such as hepatitis A, hepatitis B, diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis (DTaP), and human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccines.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is diagnosed with vivax malaria. However, the patient has a history of G6PD deficiency. Which antimalarial drug should be avoided in this case, as recommended by the 2013 malaria drug policy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Primaquine is contraindicated in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

questions.text: If the median of a dataset is greater than the mean, what can you infer about the data?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The data is negatively skewed

questions.text: Vossius ring is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blunt trauma

Explanation:

Vossius ring is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule.

It occurs due to striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.

It is smaller than the size of pupil.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve supplying the muscle marked as green
questions.solution:

The muscle is Inferior oblique. 

Supplied by 3rd Cranial Nerve.

questions.solution:

Inferior rectus.

Inferior rectus- Medial rectus- superior rectus- lateral rectus.

questions.text: Which one of following is used in retinal sealing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SF6

Explanation:

Pneumatic retinopexy (PR) is an alternative to scleral buckling for the surgical repair of selected retinal detachments.
A gas bubble is injected into the vitreous cavity, and the patient is positioned so that the bubble closes the retinal break (s), allowing absorption of the sub-retinal fluid.

Cryotherapy or laser photocoagulation is applied around the retinal break(s) to form a permanent seal.

questions.text: A female aged 65 years with uncontrolled Diabetes mellitus & hypertension presented with sudden painless loss of vision, On fundoscopy,the following image is obtained. Identfy the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ref: Read the text below

CRVO: 

The most common cause is uncontrolled hypertension followed by uncontrolled DM.

Usually it occurs in females in the 6th-7th decade.

Sudden painless loss of vision is there. 

The whole retina is full of flame shaped haemorrhages, also known as splashed tomato/tomato ketchup retina.

questions.text: The most common mode of spread of Retinoblastoma is

questions.text: Rosette shaped cataract involves which part of the lens:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior cortex

Blunt trauma results in a rosette cataract wherein the opacities are located in the posterior region. This cataract has flower-shaped appearance, the petals of which correspond to sectors of posterior opacities.

2.75-3.2 mm

choices.text: Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Shift patient to OT and cautery.
Use hemostatic agents do 3 to 4 gargles per day

questions.text: A Child underwent tonsillectomy and after surgery shifted to recovery room where he started bleeding and on examination a clot was seen at the site of surgery. Next step in management will be ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

Primary haemorrhage. 

•	Occurs at the time of operation.

•	It can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary haemorrhage. 

•	Occurs within a period of 24 h and can be controlled by simple measures such as removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.

•	Presence of a clot prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle on the vessels which pass through it (compare postpartum uterine bleeding).

Secondary haemorrhage. 

•	Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. 

•	It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.

questions.text: Interpret the audiogram given in the picture and comment on the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Otosclerosis

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

•	In this PTA, there is AB gap which is suggestive of conductive hearing loss

•	Dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve is seen in Otosclerosis ( Carhart’s Notch) Dip at 4000 Hz in AC and BC curve in audiogram is 
suggestive of noise induced hearing loss

questions.text: A trumpet blower present with left sided neck swelling. X-ray reveals following finding. Most likely diagnosis of this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngoceoele

Sol :  

•    Laryngocoele is a air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule.

•    Aquired laryngocele: Increased pressure in the laryngeal lumen wind instrument player)

•    Laryngopyocele: infected laryngocele

It may be:

•    Internal: confined within the larynx and look like distension of false cord and aryepiglottic fold.

•    External - saccule herniates through the thyroid membrane and presents in neck.

•    Mixed in which both internal and external components are seen.

Clinical Feature

•    Hoarseness, cough and if large in size then present with airway obstruction.

•    It is reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva.

Diagnosis

•    Made by indirect laryngoscopy, and soft tissue AP and lateral vies of neck with Valsalva.

Treatment

•    Internal laryngocele: treated by endoscopic laser surgery

•    External laryngocele: transcervical approach

Subglottic stenosis

Reducing postoperative granulation and scar tissue formation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with recurrent sinusitis. Surgical intervention is advised for this patient. Which of the following is gold standard investigation before endoscopic surgery like functional endoscopic sinus surgery?

Correct Answer (B)

CT scan

Sol :  

•	CT scan of sinuses will tell the extent of disease, predisposing structural abnormalities, amount of destruction of bony walls and any extension to orbit and cranial cavity.

•	Investigation of choice for diagnosis of sinusitis is also CT scan.

questions.text: 6 yr old child bought by mom with history of loss of hearing in one ear since 2 months .Study the the given otoscopic finding and comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Serous otitis Media

Most cases of bullous myringitis occur in males between the ages of 2 to 8 years old, whereas AOM is most commonly seen in children less than two years of age

questions.text: Upon endoscopy, the following structure is seen which is marked with arrow. Name this structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fossa of rosenmuller

•    Eustachian tube opening present on the lateral wall of nasopharynx, situated 1.25 cm behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate.

•    An elevation known as Torus tubarius raised by the cartilage of the tube bound the tube above and behind.

•    Above and behind the tubal elevation is a recess called fossa of Rosenmüller.

•    Fossa of Rosenmüller is the commonest site for origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

•    From lower end of torus tubarius a ridge extends to the lateral pharyngeal wall and is called salpingopharyngeal fold. It is raised by corresponding muscle

questions.text: A 6 year old child with the history of mouth breathing, high arched palate, failure to thrive and hearing loss . Which of the following will be best management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

Sol :  

•	This child is probably suffering from adenotonsillar hypertrophy which is causing recurrent respiratory tract infection and mouth breathing. 

•	Hypertrophied adenoids/tonsils might have led to Eustachian tube blockade with a resultant SOM which explains decreased hearing. 

•	So the treatment is Myringotomy with grommet insertion along with Adeno-tonsillectomy in the same sitting.

•	Myringoplasty is the surgical repair of TM and is done in CSOM.

questions.text: A patient presents to ENT OPD with pulsatile tinnitus, reddish mass behind tympanic membrane. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glomus tumour

Sol :  

Glomus Tumors (Paragangliomas, Chemodectomas)

Glomus Tumor: slow growing, benign tumor although locally destructive (expansive, bone eroding) of the chemoreceptive cells (paraganglion cells, neural crest in origin) distributed along parasympathetic nerves in the base of skull, neck, and chest

• Most common benign tumor of the temporal bone of adults (rare in pediatrics)
Glomus Vagale: arise from paraganglia around the vagus nerve at the base of skull

• SSx: pulsatile tinnitus (most common symptom), hearing loss, cranial nerve palsies, aural discharge, otalgia, dizziness (invasion of the labyrinth), reddish middle ear mass, BROWN’S SIGN (BLANCHING OF THE TM WITH POSITIVE PRESSURE)

• Rx: surgical resection after preoperative embolization or primary
radiation therapy for nonoperable candidates, advanced tumors, or presence of residual disease

questions.text: Battle sign is defined as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ecchymosis on Mastoid

Sol :  

Battle’s sign appears as a large bruise that extends across the entire backside of your ear, and it may also extend out to the upper part of your neck.

questions.text: A 14 year old boy presents with reddish nasal mass, profuse epistaxis & Proptosis. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Juvenile nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

Sol :  

•	Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. 

•	It’s a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. 

•	Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. 

•	Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide ( androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss.

•	Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.

•	Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson’s transpalatal approach. But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision.

questions.text: In view of mucormycosis - the least possible cause could be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Broad spectrum antibiotics

Sol :  

•	Rhinocerebral mucormycosis is a rare opportunistic infection of the sinuses, nasal passages, oral cavity, and brain caused by saprophytic fungi. The infection can rapidly result in death. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis commonly affects individuals with diabetes and those in immunocompromised states.

•	Saprophytic aerobic fungi of the class Phycomycetes (order Mucorales) cause rhinocerebral mucormycosis, also known as phycomycosis. The 3 genera responsible for most cases are Rhizopus, Absidia, and Mucor

Treatment of rhinocerebral mucormycosis includes the following:

•	Reversing underlying immunocompromised states

•	Administering systemic antifungals

•	Performing urgent surgical debridement

➣	Correcting hypoxia, acidosis, hyperglycemia, and electrolyte abnormalities is critical to the successful management of this condition.

➣	Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (GCSF) can be administered to reconstitute host defenses and to enhance leukocytosis.

➣	Dexamethasone has been used to treat brain edema. 

➣	Hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy has been used in an attempt to control the infection. 

➣	Amphotericin B is the only reliable systemic antifungal agent approved for the treatment of mucormycosis, and the highest possible tissue levels should be achieved.
